findings.description: The kill() function allows any owner to selfdestruct the library contract via delegatecall. Since WalletProxy uses delegatecall, calling kill() from a proxy will destroy the shared library, breaking ALL proxy wallets that depend on it.
findings.reasoning: This correctly identifies the documented Parity multi-sig wallet vulnerability. The kill() function in the library can be called by any owner through a proxy, causing selfdestruct of the shared library and freezing all dependent wallets. The attack scenario and impact description are accurate.

findings.description: The initWallet() function has no access control and can be called by anyone at any time, allowing an attacker to front-run legitimate initialization and take control of the wallet.
findings.reasoning: This is a real, independent vulnerability not mentioned in the ground truth. The initWallet() function has no access control and can be called by anyone. An attacker can front-run initialization to become the sole owner, permanently locking out legitimate users. This is a material vulnerability with concrete exploit steps and no trusted role required.

target_assessment.type_match_reasoning: Finding 0 uses 'Unprotected Selfdestruct in Delegatecall Library' which accurately describes the access_control vulnerability in kill(). The terminology matches the ground truth's description of the Parity vulnerability.

root_cause_identification.reasoning: The explanation correctly identifies that the kill() function in the library can be called via delegatecall from any proxy, causing the shared library to selfdestruct. This is the exact root cause of the Parity vulnerability.

attack_vector_validity.reasoning: The attack scenario is realistic and executable: any owner of any wallet can call kill() through their proxy, which delegatecalls to the library, causing selfdestruct. This matches the documented historical exploit.

fix_suggestion_validity.reasoning: The suggested fix (removing kill() from the library or implementing it at proxy level) would completely remediate the issue by preventing the shared library from being destroyed.

notes: The audit correctly identified the target vulnerability (Finding 0) and also found a valid bonus vulnerability (Finding 1) - the unprotected initWallet() function. Both are real issues in the code. The Parity vulnerability was historically catastrophic ($150M+ frozen), making Finding 0 critically important. Finding 1 is also severe as it allows complete wallet takeover by front-running initialization.
